journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Bioactive and Compatible Polymers

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL, USA

author-notes.corresp: Idris Cerkez, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, USA. Email: idriscerkez@auburn.edu

abstract.p: Two new N-halamine polyelectrolytes were synthesized, characterized, and deposited onto cotton fabric from a water solution using a layer-by-layer assembly technique. The fabrics were rendered biocidal by a dilute household bleach solution and challenged with Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. The chlorinated swatches (five bilayer coated) inactivated ~106 Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli O157:H7 within only 2 min of contact time. Although the coatings were susceptible to hydrolysis when exposed to repeated washing, the stability of the system was improved by a posttreatment with a cross-linking agent, 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Health-care-associated infections are a significant public health problem due to an increasing number of contact by people, the emergence of new types of microorganisms, and the increasing bacterial resistance to antibiotics that has led to the emergence of superbugs, such as Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus.1 Cross-infection is the main reason for health-care-associated infections, and so the development of biocidal surfaces that inactive microorganisms on contact is critical.2 Textile materials, particularly cellulosic fibers, are superior for the growth of bacteria, some of which can survive more than 90 days on these materials.3 In this respect, immobilizations of antimicrobials, such as light activated compounds,4,5 quaternary ammonium salts,6 –9 synthetic mimics of antimicrobial peptides,10,11 silver ions,12,13 N-halamines,14 –18 and others have been extensively utilized to prevent surface contamination.

The N-halamines are among the most effective biocides used to inactivate a broad spectrum of microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, yeasts, and fungi. The inactivation mechanism involves transfer of the oxidative halogen directly to the microbial cell membrane that leads to cell death,19 whereas the less stable N-halamines may also involve inactivation caused by oxidative free halogen formed via dissociation of the nitrogen–halogen bond through hydrolysis.20 The stability of the nitrogen–halogen bond increases from imide- to amide- to amine-containing N-halamines, due to the presence of electron-donating substituents adjacent to the nitrogen atom.21 N-halamines provide long-lasting biocidal coatings in a manner, such that once the oxidative halogen is consumed, it can be simply recharged by exposure to dilute household bleach.

Since cellulosic materials have been widely used in the medical textile industry, antimicrobial cellulose incorporation of N-halamines has been studied extensively. The efforts in this regard include covalent bonding of N-halamines on the cellulose surface through grafting,22,23 tethering,24,25 and copolymerization.26,27 We reported that N-halamines can be immobilized electrostatically on cotton fabric using a layer-by-layer (LbL) technique.28 Even though the coating exhibited superior washing stability, only about 104 reduction of S. aureus and Escherichia coli O157:H7 within 5 min was observed (by 0.21 wt% Cl+), with the biocidal activity being provided by hindered amine-containing N-halamines. However, greater activation of bacterial within shorter times is desired especially in the health-care environment. Therefore, in this study, new anionic and cationic polyelectrolytes, functionalized with amide and imide antimicrobes, were synthesized and coated on cotton fabric using a LbL assembly technique in order to provide more rapid inactivation on surfaces.

sec.title: Materials and instrumentation
sec.p: Hydantoinyl acrylamide-co-2-acrylamido-2-methyl-1-propanesulfonic acid sodium salt (SA), methanol, and potassium persulfate were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Company (Milwaukee, WI). Diacetone acrylamide and trimethyl-2-methacryloxyethylammonium chloride (QM) were obtained from VWR (Radnor, PA) and used without further purification. Desized, scoured, and bleached (100%) cotton (Style 400 Cotton Print Cloth) was obtained from Testfabrics, Inc. (West Pittson, PA). Clorox® brand (Clorox, Inc., Oakland, CA) household bleach was used for chlorination. Bacteria cultures of S. aureus ATCC 6538 and E. coli O157:H7 ATCC 43895 were purchased from American Type Culture Collection (Rockville, MD), and Trypticase soy agar was obtained from Difco Laboratories (Detroit, MI).

Nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded using a Bruker 400 MHz spectrometer. A Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectrometer with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) accessory utilizing a diamond crystal was used to obtain ATR-IR data recorded with 64 scans at 4 cm-1 resolution.

sec.title: LbL coating, posttreatment, and chlorination
sec.p: The N and P polyelectrolytes (2%) were dissolved in water in separate glass containers, and bleached cotton fabric was alternatively soaked in these solutions beginning with the cationic polymer. To ensure reasonable attraction, the first dip was for 5 min, whereas the subsequent dips were for 1 min. Between each dipping, the swatches were rinsed with distilled water to remove loose polyelectrolytes and then dried at 100°C for 5 min. This process was repeated until the desired number of bilayers was reached; then the swatches were vigorously washed with 0.5 wt% detergent water for 15 min at room temperature.

The posttreatment with 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane (GPTMS) followed the LbL coating, and it was accomplished by dissolving the specified amount of the cross-linking agent in ethanol and subsequently coating the swatches using a laboratory wringer. The fabrics were then cured at 120°C for 1 h and then vigorously washed with 0.5 wt% detergent water for 15 min at room temperature.

The coated swatches were chlorinated with 10 wt% Clorox solution at pH 7 for 1 h. After rinsing with distilled water, the fabrics were stored at 45°C for 1 h to remove occluded chlorine from the surface. The Cl+% on the swatches were determined by iodometric/thiosulfate titration, and the chlorine loading was calculated according to equation (1):
The Cl+% is the wt% of the oxidative chlorine on the samples; N and V are the normality (equiv/L) and volume (L) of Na2S2O3 (titrant), respectively; and W is the weight of the cotton sample in grams.

sec.title: Stability tests
sec.p: The American Association of Textile Chemists and Colorists (AATCC) test method 61-1996 was employed to evaluate the wash fastness of the coatings. In this procedure, stainless steel beads were used to agitate 2.54 cm × 5.08 cm swatches in a canister filled with 150 mL of 0.15 wt% AATCC detergent water solution. The canisters were rotated at 42 rpm at 49°C in a laboratory model Lauder-Ometer. Forty-five minutes rotation of the machine was taken as equivalent to five machine washings; the swatches were washed with 5, 10, 25, and 50 washing cycles. The chlorine stability was evaluated by measuring the remaining chlorine loadings after each washing cycle (X columns, Table 1). The durability of the coating was analyzed by rechlorination of the swatches after each washing cycle (Y columns, Table 1). To simulate household machine washings, 10 wt% Clorox was added into a canister, so that the N-halamines would be recharged during the washings. The remaining chlorine loadings were measured after the washing cycles and a drying step at 45°C for 1 h.

caption.p: Stability toward washing of coatings on cotton (Cl+% remaining)a.

fn.p: GPTMS: 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane; A: number of washing cycles; X: the remaining chlorine after the washing; Y: the retained chlorine amount after the washing on rechlorination; Z: the remaining chlorine amount after the washing in the presence of 10% Clorox.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The error in the measured Cl+ weight percentage values was ±0.01.

sec.p: An accelerated weathering tester (Q-panel Company, Cleveland, OH) was used to evaluate the ultraviolet (UVA) light stability of the coatings. Both the chlorinated and the nonchlorinated swatches were placed in the tester for 1 d; the restored chlorine loadings were also measured. This process was repeated up to 72 h.

sec.title: Antimicrobial efficacy testing
sec.p: Antimicrobial efficacies of the swatches (both the chlorinated and the nonchlorinated) were evaluated against S. aureus (ATCC 6538) and E. coli O157:H7 (ATCC 43895) by conducting a modified AATCC “sandwich test.” In this procedure, the bacteria was suspended in 100 mM phosphate buffer (pH 7) to produce a suspension of known population, and 25 µL of this suspension was placed on a 2.54 cm × 2.54 cm swatch. Then an identical swatch was placed on top, and a sterile weight was placed on top to ensure sufficient contact with the microorganisms. The swatches were quenched with 5.0 mL of 0.02 N sodium thiosulfate and vortexed for 2 min after the specified contact times. Then serial dilutions were prepared using 100 mM phosphate buffer solution (pH 7) and plated on Trypticase soy agar plates. The plates were incubated at 37°C for 24 h, and the viable bacteria were counted for antimicrobial efficacy analysis.

sec.title: Polymer synthesis and characterization
sec.p: Hydantoin acrylamide (HA) monomer was synthesized according to a previous procedure.29 The polyelectrolytes N and P were synthesized by free radical polymerization as shown in Scheme 1.

caption.p: Synthesis of copolymer N and P.

sec.p: The final composition of the copolymer N was obtained for m/n to be 1/1 based on the NMR spectra (Figure 1). The intrinsic viscosity of the copolymer determined using the dilute solution viscosity technique was found to be 0.39 dL/g (in 0.1 M NaCl aqueous solution).

caption.p: 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the synthesized copolymer N (solvent: D2O).

sec.p: The structure of the copolymer P was confirmed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Figure 2), and from those spectra, the compositions of the monomer in the copolymer structure were found to be m = 1 and n = 1. The intrinsic viscosity of the copolymer determined using a dilute solution viscosity technique was found to be 0.37 dL/g (in 0.1 M NaCl aqueous solution).

caption.p: 1H and 13C NMR spectra of the synthesized copolymer P (solvent: D2O).

sec.title: Characterization of the coatings
sec.p: The coatings were characterized using ATR-IR spectroscopy. As seen in Figure 3, two additional bands, 1722 and 1772 cm-1, corresponding to the amide (cyclic and acyclic) and imide vibrational stretching mode bands of the hydantoin ring present in the polyelectrolytes structure appeared in the spectra after 5 BL coating. The carbonyl stretching mode bands of the ester groups could not be distinguished due to overlap with the amide stretching mode bands at 1722 cm-1. When the coated swatches were chlorinated, both the amide and the imide vibrational mode bands shifted to a higher wavenumber due to the disruption of hydrogen bonds.26

caption.p: FTIR characterization of the coatings: (a) cotton fabric, (b) coated cotton fabric (5 BL coated), and (c) coated and then chlorinated cotton fabric (5 BL coated).

sec.p: Deposition of the polyelectrolytes was further evidenced by measuring the chlorine loadings of the chlorinated swatches having different BLs. A linear increase in measured chlorine loadings with respect to the increasing number of BL was obtained indicating a linear film growth. Prior work indicated that N-halamine coatings exhibit superior biocidal activity when the chlorine loading on cotton is ~0.20 wt%.30 As can be seen in Figure 4, an equivalent chlorine loading could be obtained with only 5 BL deposition of these copolymers, which is much less than in the previous study.28 Therefore, 5 BL coated swatches were used for the following stability and biocidal efficacy analyses.

caption.p: Effect of number of bilayers deposited on chlorine loadings.

sec.title: Washing stability
sec.p: The washing stability of the coatings is reported in Table 1. In the X column, all the oxidative chlorine was removed with the first washing cycle (five machine washings) when there was no posttreatment with GPTMS. Moreover, the coatings were not durable toward repeated washings as evidenced by the Y and Z columns.

To improve the stability of the N–Cl bond and the durability of the coatings, a posttreatment with GPTMS after the LbL coating was performed. The cross-linking of the fabrics greatly improved the results (Table 1, Y and Z columns) even with small amounts of GPTMS. When the swatches were treated with 1 wt% GPTMS, ~50% of the coating remained on the surface (Y column) even after 50 machine washings. Moreover, when bleach was introduced into the wash, the coatings became more durable, such that ~75% of the initial chlorine loadings remained after 50 washing cycles. In brief, the increasing GPTMS concentration reduced the amount of the coating being washed away from the surface, whereas it did not affect the chlorine stability (X columns). Considering the normal use of bleach in washes, as in the Z column, the 1 wt% GPTMS-treated swatches would provide sufficient stabilities over 50 machine washings. The rapid dissociation of the N–Cl bonds of the HA comonomer with repeated laundering was also observed in a previous study.29

sec.title: UVA light stability
sec.p: Both the chlorinated and nonchlorinated swatches were placed in a weathering chamber and exposed to UVA light at times, up to 72 h. As seen in Table 2, the oxidative chlorine loadings gradually decreased as the UVA light exposure time increased. The swatches lost their effective chlorine loadings within 24 h of UVA exposure. This loss could be due to N–Cl bond dissociation and/or a decomposition taking place in the structure. To investigate the reason for this loss, both the chlorinated and the nonchlorinated swatches were chlorinated after each 24 h UVA exposure. When the chlorinated swatches were rechlorinated for the first time, ~75% of the initial chlorine was restored, indicating that the loss within the first 24 h was mostly due to N–Cl bond dissociation. However, when these swatches were exposed for another 24 h to UVA light, only ~40% of the initial chlorine was regenerated. After the third rechlorination, the swatches could not be recharged sufficiently for an effective biocidal activity (0.05 wt% Cl+),31 whereas the nonchlorinated samples were fully charged by each rechlorination. As observed in previous studies,30 an irreversible decomposition induced by UVA light exposure occurs when the samples were chlorinated.

caption.p: Stability to UVA light exposure by the coatings on cotton (Cl+% remaining)a.

fn.label: a
fn.p: The error in the measured Cl+ weight percentage values was ±0.01.

sec.title: Biocidal efficacy
sec.p: The biocidal efficacies of 5 BL coated swatches were evaluated against ~106 of S. aureus and E. coli O157:H7 from 2 to 30 min. To address the effect of posttreatment on the biocidal efficacy, the swatches were tested both before and after the posttreatment with GPTMS (Table 3). The control samples, which were nonchlorinated, did not provide significant reduction within 30 min of contact time. The limited reduction that they exhibited was due to adhesion of the bacteria to the surface. However, the chlorinated swatches exhibited complete inactivation of the Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria within 2 min after contact. Moreover, the posttreated swatches were as effective as the nontreated swatches indicating that the cross-linking imparted by the posttreatment does not affect the chlorine diffusion throughout the layers.

caption.p: Biocidal efficacies of the treated cotton fabrics.

fn.p: LbL = 5 BL coated swatches, LbL-GPTMS = 5 BL coated swatches, and then posttreated with 1% 3-glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: N-halamine polyelectrolytes with amide and imide groups for chlorination sights were synthesized, characterized, and deposited onto cotton fabric via a LbL assembly technique. A linear relationship between the chlorine loadings and the number of BL deposited was obtained; an effective biocidal coating was obtained with only 5 BL deposed on copolymers from a water 0.2 wt% solution. The coatings were susceptible to hydrolysis by repeated laundering. However, a posttreatment with GPTMS drastically improved the washing stability. The chlorinated swatches exhibited potent antimicrobial activities against S. aureus and E. coli O157:H7 with ~106 inactivation within 2 min after contact. This rapid inactivation of bacteria by these polyelectrolytes provides potential applications for medical textiles, apparel, hygiene products, food packaging, and the filtration industry.

ack.p: The author acknowledges helpful discussion with postdoctoral mentor Prof. S. D. Worley and assistance in biocidal testing by Prof. Tung S. Huang.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This work was supported by US Air Force through Grant FA8650-07-1-5908.
